awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: An Advanced Analytics Platform for Personalized Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to revolutionize the current approach to decision-making processes in disease treatment. The project will help transform how patients, their families, and healthcare providers navigate the complex landscape of disease treatment options. It aspires to empower these stakeholders with personalized, data-driven treatment recommendations, considering a comprehensive set of individual patient attributes and real-world variables such as the location, budget, and insurance details. By making disease treatment more personalized and efficient, the project is poised to significantly improve treatment outcomes and reduce healthcare costs. Furthermore, its commercial potential is substantial, given the growing need for personalized healthcare solutions and the rise of artificial intelligence-powered applications in healthcare.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of artificial intelligence-powered platform that provides personalized disease treatment recommendations. The innovation lies in leveraging advanced machine learning algorithms to analyze a wide array of patient-specific and disease-specific data, leading to more accurate treatment suggestions tailored to each individual patient's unique circumstances and features. The project aims to address the problem of overwhelming and often confusing treatment options by providing clear, data-backed suggestions via the developed platform. By doing so, it offers an opportunity to enhance the treatment decision-making process and ultimately improve the quality of patient care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This project focused on developing a portable testbed and software platform (called “SmarTreatMate”) that leverages cutting-edge machine learning—specifically, federated learning—to help oncologists select more personalized treatments for cancer patients. Over the life of the award, the I-Corps team conducted extensive stakeholder interviews, developed a minimally viable product (MVP), and refined our approach to ensure the solution addresses real-world needs in cancer care.

Project Outcomes and Findings

  1. Testbed Development and Demonstration
    • The team created a portable hardware-software testbed equipped with an NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin Developer Kit, a touch-sensitive display, a noise-canceling microphone, and wireless peripherals. This setup allows healthcare professionals to experiment with advanced machine learning algorithms in various clinical settings without compromising patient data privacy.
  2. Federated Learning for Privacy and Accuracy
    • The developed platform uses federated learning to train predictive models across multiple locations without moving sensitive data offsite. This approach helps preserve patient privacy (an essential requirement in healthcare) while still benefiting from collaborative data analysis.
  3. Stakeholder Engagement and Validation
    • Through 157 interviews with oncologists, hospital administrators, nurses, cancer patients, and other healthcare stakeholders, the I-Corps team gained invaluable insights into practical challenges. These findings guided iterative improvements to our MVP and ensured alignment with clinical workflows.
  4. Customer Discovery and Market Fit
    • By participating in NSF I-Corps and conducting further market research, we refined our business model to address the specific needs of oncologists and cancer centers. The solution aims to reduce treatment failures, improve patient outcomes, and potentially lower overall healthcare costs by recommending more targeted therapies.

Intellectual Merit

  • Technical Advancements: The I-Corps team introduced feature-based clustering methods within a federated learning framework to better handle diverse clinical data, which can include imaging, laboratory results, and patient histories.
  • Survival Analysis Innovation: The project explored how federated learning can enhance survival analysis for cancer patients, potentially leading to more accurate treatment recommendations that adapt to emerging data in near real-time.
  • Scalable Infrastructure: The portable testbed and the accompanying software stack demonstrate how distributed machine learning can be deployed cost-effectively across multiple clinical settings.

Broader Impacts

  • Enhanced Patient Care: By enabling more precise and personalized treatment plans, our platform has the potential to improve patient outcomes, especially for complex cancers.
  • Data Privacy and Security: Federated learning preserves patient confidentiality and could serve as a model for secure data sharing in healthcare, boosting trust and collaboration among hospitals and research centers.
  • Educational and Workforce Development: Students and researchers gained hands-on experience in advanced machine learning techniques, entrepreneurial practices, and interdisciplinary teamwork. These experiences contribute to a more skilled workforce ready to tackle future challenges in healthcare innovation.
  • Pathway to Commercialization: The customer discovery efforts and pitch deck preparations have laid the groundwork for expanding SmarTreatMate beyond a prototype into a commercial venture, potentially benefiting a wide range of healthcare providers and patients.

Summary
In summary, this project advanced the application of federated learning for personalized cancer treatment, culminating in a portable testbed and an evolving software platform. By integrating stakeholder feedback, focusing on privacy-preserving machine learning, and demonstrating clinical relevance, the I-Corps team made excellent progress toward improving cancer care outcomes and broadening the impact of cutting-edge AI technologies in healthcare.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2025
Modified by: Sajal K Das

Overview

Over the life of the award, the I-Corps team conducted extensive stakeholder interviews, developed a minimally viable product (MVP), and refined our approach to ensure the solution addresses real-world needs in cancer care.


Project Outcomes and Findings

Testbed Development and      Demonstration 

The team created a       portable hardware-software testbed equipped with an NVIDIA Jetson AGX       Orin Developer Kit, a touch-sensitive display, a noise-canceling       microphone, and wireless peripherals. This setup allows healthcare       professionals to experiment with advanced machine learning algorithms in       various clinical settings without compromising patient data privacy.

The developed platform uses federated learning to train       predictive models across multiple locations without moving sensitive data       offsite. These findings guided iterative improvements to our MVP and ensured       alignment with clinical workflows.

The solution aims to       reduce treatment failures, improve patient outcomes, and potentially       lower overall healthcare costs by recommending more targeted therapies.

Survival Analysis Innovation: The project explored how      federated learning can enhance survival analysis for cancer patients,      potentially leading to more accurate treatment recommendations that adapt      to emerging data in near real-time.
Scalable Infrastructure: The portable testbed and the      accompanying software stack demonstrate how distributed machine learning      can be deployed cost-effectively across multiple clinical settings.

Data Privacy      and Security: Federated learning preserves patient confidentiality and could      serve as a model for secure data sharing in healthcare, boosting trust and      collaboration among hospitals and research centers.

These experiences contribute to a more skilled      workforce ready to tackle future challenges in healthcare innovation.
Pathway to      Commercialization: The customer discovery efforts and pitch deck preparations have      laid the groundwork for expanding SmarTreatMate beyond a prototype into a      commercial venture, potentially benefiting a wide range of healthcare      providers and patients.

By integrating stakeholder feedback, focusing on privacy-preserving machine learning, and demonstrating clinical relevance, the I-Corps team made excellent progress toward improving cancer care outcomes and broadening the impact of cutting-edge AI technologies in healthcare.
